name: Coq Au Vin
headline: Coq Au Vin
description: Cook Ina Garten's top-rated recipe for classic French Coq Au Vin from Barefoot Contessa on Food Network with Burgundy wine, cremini mushrooms and pancetta.
keywords: Chicken Stew,Chicken Recipes,Poultry,Stew Recipes,European Recipes,French Recipes,Vegetable,Bacon Recipes,Meat,Mushroom,Carrot Recipes,Main Dish
recipeIngredient: 4 ounces good bacon or pancetta, diced
Kosher salt and freshly ground black pepper
1/2 pound carrots, cut diagonally in 1-inch pieces
1/2 bottle (375 ml) good dry red wine such as Burgundy
1 cup good chicken stock, preferably homemade
2 tablespoons unsalted butter, at room temperature, divided
1/2 pound cremini mushrooms, stems removed and thickly sliced

recipeInstructions.text: Preheat the oven to 250 degrees F.
Heat the olive oil in a large Dutch oven. Add the bacon and cook over medium heat for 8 to 10 minutes, until lightly browned. Remove the bacon to a plate with a slotted spoon.

Meanwhile, lay the chicken out on paper towels and pat dry. Liberally sprinkle the chicken on both sides with salt and pepper. When the bacon is removed, brown the chicken pieces in batches in a single layer for about 5 minutes, turning to brown evenly. Remove the chicken to the plate with the bacon and continue to brown until all the chicken is done. Set aside.

Add the carrots, onions, 2 teaspoons salt, and 1 teaspoon pepper to the pan and cook over medium heat for 10 to 12 minutes, stirring occasionally, until the onions are lightly browned. Add the garlic and cook for 1 more minute. Add the Cognac and put the bacon, chicken, and any juices that collected on the plate into the pot. Add the wine, chicken stock, and thyme and bring to a simmer. Cover the pot with a tight fitting lid and place in the oven for 30 to 40 minutes, until the chicken is just not pink. Remove from the oven and place on top of the stove.

Mash 1 tablespoon of butter and the flour together and stir into the stew. Add the frozen onions. In a medium saute pan, add the remaining 1 tablespoon of butter and cook the mushrooms over medium-low heat for 5 to 10 minutes, until browned. Add to the stew. Bring the stew to a simmer and cook for another 10 minutes. Season to taste. Serve hot.

review.reviewBody: Barefoot Contessa has improved the recipe to make it easy for a week nite. I had no trouble throwing this together with quality ingredients on a Tuesday night. Quartered chicken is best, as I did thighs once and it wasn‚Äôt enough variety. I like the steps here as they save a lot of time putting this together for the oven. Top buttery mashed potatoes with this!
Delicious!
I have a question---for 6 may I simply double the recipe? thank you!

Solid base recipe and technique. Like any stew, we all have our additions and such. I like to use only dark meat and also roast off a few sweet orange peppers sliced in strips, baby potatoes and portabellos (sliced and halved for more substantial chew) on a hotel sheet instead of sauteing. Not a fan of roux in general. Just add a handful or two of orzo for the same result without the raw flour taste risk. Same with chili. Also add frozen peas with the frozen pearls.
I made this a couple of days ago and followed the recipe exactly.   Absolutely wonderful.   Delicious.  We all loved it.   Wish I had known about it sooner.
Absolutely delicious! Followed the directions as they were written and it came out perfect! Thank you Ina, for another fabulous dish!

I made this recipe last week and was delighted with the results! In my opinion, the level is Intermediate due to the number of steps. I varied the process somewhat, I cut the breasts in half with kitchen shears to match the thighs, sprinkled both with salt, pepper, and Herbes de Provence, and roasted them on two parchment-lined pans at 400 degrees for 20 minutes to give color and flavor. Then I added the browned bacon together with all the ingredients but the butter and flour to a crockpot with 1T Herbes de Provence. I omitted the cognac and used 1/4 bottle of wine with 11/2c chicken bone broth. I set for 30' on high then 8 hours on low. Then I added the flour and butter mixture and simmered on low for 30'. It was fabulous! I plan to serve this for our Christmas Party after de-boneing for ease of serving. I am a huge fan of Ina Garten and use her recipes often.
Delicious!  Wow!   Wouldn't change a thing!

I‚Äôve made this twice now.  I add a touch more cognac, use a nice wine, and at least double the garlic.  I think the key is to let it simmer for quite a bit, especially because of the flour that is added at the end. Oh, and I used the whole bundle of thyme.  It was delicious.
Delicious, Ina never disappoints.

Unfortunately, this did not come out so great for us.  I have made Ina's Beef Bourguignon before, and that has turned out amazing!! This recipe is quite similar but obviously uses chicken instead of beef.  We found the alcohol taste to be quite strong...not sure if that was from the Cognac or the wine.  I had a hard time eating it, though.  My kids scarfed down the Beef Bourguignon when I made it, but they were less than pleased with this dish.  I don't think I will make it again, unfortunately.  I almost never have a problem with Ina's recipes, as they are just always so wonderful!  This one was not a winner for us.

üòã Turned out so delicious. I will absolutely make this recipe again. For those who are concerned about the oven temperature, the Dutch oven is essential to cook the chicken thoroughly. If you increase the temperature, you could dry out the chicken‚Ä¶even in the stew. I wouldn‚Äôt change a thing about the recipe!

I've always wanted to make Coq Au Vin and felt intimidated. This. was. wonderful! Easy to follow directions and so comforting and full of flavor. My only regret is not getting a loaf of crusty bread or a baguette to soak up the yummy juices. Even better on day 2!
I've made this numerous times and LOVE it.  I don't change a thing.  People that completely change a recipe and then rate the original annoy me.  lol

I'm sorry I tried this one.Coq Au Vin started out as a peasant recipe..and with these ingredients ( definitely not peasant) I was really hoping  for a lot more than this delivered. ( used the same ingredients, and followed each step.)  Will look for a recipe  that suits my family. No harm, no Fowl. üòÅ

Followed this recipe to the letter and made coq au vin. It was, at best, ok. Nobody was disgusted by it, but nobody was impressed with it. And when you think back to all the hours you spent toiling over each and every step, that really impresses upon you how terrible this recipe is. Thankfully I‚Äôve gotten another coq au vin recipe from a friend and it‚Äôs less time consuming and more flavorful.

Absolutely delicious. This quickly became my family‚Äôs favorite meal. I do add a half tablespoon of dried Herbs de Provence and use about 4-5 cloves of garlic. A GOOD red wine and cognac make all the difference. Don‚Äôt cheap out on the wine.

I've always been curious about cooking up a Coq Au Vin. Happy to find a recipe from my favorite Ina Garten.  I followed the recipe to the letter but wasn't thrilled with the finished product.  If I try it again I'll add more flavor somehow - maybe more and different herbs, a bit more garlic? Don't misunderstand, it was a comforting dish but just didn't bowl us over.

When it‚Äôs just family, choosing the chicken part you love best is just fine. But when I‚Äôm entertaining , everyone gets the same cut and in this case thighs. My thighs were large at 8 oz. each. No! The chicken had large thighs. Everything was browned maybe not in Inas order but they came out beautifully. Don‚Äôt crowd the pan. The first time I‚Äôve successfully flambe‚Äôd anything. That was fun. Not sure if that was on the website or the book. It‚Äôs early November and the little onions are just coming in to the stores in Hawaii. I chose Anne Bs cipollinne onions over the Pearl but a mix would be fun. I added gold potatoes but won‚Äôt next time‚Äîgood for family but not a guest presentation.
I cooked the thighs for 20 minutes at 350 then added the potatoes(cut into 8ths) mushrooms and cipollines for 20 more with the roux. It was perfect, flavor up the yin yang. I did add 3 bay leaves, sprigs of Rosemary and thyme branches. Not sure yer if this will be on my ny recipe in two weeks or not but it is a winner. I can see Rosemary mashed potatoes or thick pieces of garlic bread to soak up the juices.
Made this exactly as written and loved it! Perfect for a New Years Eve dinner on a dreary winter day.

Very easy Coq au Vin recipe. I used smoked tuna instead of bacon, mushroom broth, bourbon with a bit of apple juice in replacement of cognac, and omitted the pearl onions. Basically you can make a number of substitutes. With the leftovers, I am going to try straining and blending the carrots, onions and broth to see if i like it refined/less chunky . Served with baguette and oven baked french fries with garlic

I loved this recipe.  I add more wine and chicken stock to make more of a stew.  Plus my Dutch oven doesn't have a strong seal so some of the liquid evaporates out.  I eat the chicken and the stew on a plate and in a bowl respectively.  Agree with many of the views that the chicken needs to be cooked longer or at a higher temperature to make it fall of the bone.  The only other thing I might change is adding more fresh herbs of various kinds like rosemary and/or oregano.  Otherwise, very very delicious.  This is an old fashioned warm tasty food.  It is not meant to be spicy.

Oh my GOD, this is THE best Coq au Vin I've ever made. Followed to the letter except I didn't have brandy so I substituted Gentleman Jack.

This would make an EPIC Holiday meal.

Thank you so much for posting!!!

Pretty fantastic!  I don‚Äôt like pearl onions so I left them out.  Didn‚Äôt have pancetta or bacon so I left that out too.  Thyme can be a bit overpowering so I used dried marjoram and parsley instead.  Very happy with the results.  It‚Äôs definitely a repeatable offense üòä
Exelent!!!

DEVINE! I had to substitute the cognac with white cooking wine and apple juice and substituted the burgundy wine with Pinot noir that was about a week past drinking but perfect for cooking with. A helpful hint if you can‚Äôt find the small onions frozen- they‚Äôre in the produce section and just boil them for 2 mins and put into an ice bath and they pop out of their skins very easily. Didn‚Äôt need to add any seasoning- absolutely delicious!!

I followed the recipe and it just wasn't to my taste in the end.¬† I would have used far more carrots because I love them, the little onions at the end needed something......maybe a little saute, and the beurre Mani√© didn't thicken as well as I would have liked.¬† I like her Chicken Marbella (my usual company go-to) MUCH better.
So rich and savory. A little much to make on a work night but will definitely make again for a weekend dinner or for guests. Changed nothing.
I‚Äôve been making this recipe for years.  It does take a bit of time to make but my family always enjoys it.
I omitted the brandy and pearl onions and instead added a tad more wine and the whites of 3 green onions. This was beyond delicious! Can‚Äôt what to make it again

Delicious. I used brandy, an inexpensive but full-bodies Chilean cab, and a bag of inexpensive, frozen chicken legs. My tiny local grocer did not have pearl onions or other small onions, so this wasn't exactly the traditional coq au vin, but it sure was good. I upped the garlic, our preference, throwing in three smashed, unminced cloves. Next time I'll double the mushrooms.¬†
So delicious!

Made this for the first time - absolutely ‚Äúmagnifique‚Äù!! ¬†FYI - I used chicken thighs - sooo good! Aside from that, I followed the recipe ‚Äúexactement‚Äù, BUT I did use regular pearl onions (couldn‚Äôt find frozen); just threw them in boiling water for a few minutes, to make them easy to peel üëçüèªüë©‚Äçüç≥ Not sure why this is listed as an ‚Äúintermediate‚Äúrecipe; it‚Äôs easy-peasy and soooooo ‚Äúincroyable‚Äù!¬†

Used fresh cippolini onions instead of frozen small white. Added a wonderful flavor. Searing the mushrooms in a separate pan and adding them at the end vs cooking them in the stew is a game changer. Also love the idea of mixing flour with softened butter and adding at the end. Will use these techniques again. This is a delicious hearty dish that can be served as is or spooned over mash potatoes.

This is really an amazing recipe. I usually use thighs, legs and breasts for this recipe. I also use cognac vs brandy...and just a teeny bit more then suggested! I serve roasted root veggies on the side which is delish! Great bread....and you have a wonderful dish!

Deliciouso recipe!!!   This is my 2nd time making it and I have made some changes to enhance the flavour by adding rosemary, sage, and Bay leaves.   Don't give me the bland story.   You're just not doing it right.

This recipe is so easy to make! And it's only one pot that is needed: Least amount of dishes to clean! It was my first time making coq au vin as well as first time eating it. It sort of taste like beef stew. Beef stew without tomato flavor. I served this with some good crusty bread from our local bakery.¬†

This recipe was amazing! Made it for my family and they loved it to. I paired it with a coconut rice recipe I found on here which went perfectly with it. The only thing you might want to add a bit less salt if you don‚Äôt like a lot of salt but we were pleased with the outcome.
Amazingly delicious!  My entire family loved it from age 2 to 62!

Easy recipe to follow. It turned out wonderfully!! Sauce was thicked just enough.  Chicken was tender, I kept skin on, I think the fat added to the sauce, veg not over cooked. I made Italian bread to go with...needed something to pick up the sauce. Perfect dish for company or as a good comfort dish.

Prepared meal exactly as written and it was excellent. It's just the two of us so we had enough for next night leftovers. If I were to make any changes I would add more carrots. Will definitely make again.

Lightly flouring chicken helps it brown and gives sauce a little more body. Otherwise I made as directed using bourdeax and cognac. Next time I'll cut the cognac in half as it was a bit overpowering. All in all this turned out well and I will make it again.¬†
Excellente....

Excellent dish! My entire family loves it. I have made it 4 or 5 times now and it is is rich and delicious each time. The only thing I have experienced is needing to add a lot more flour to thicken it up to my preference.
Came out wonderful. Very easy recipe to follow. Elegant and rustic dinner to impress guests. Served with side of mashed potatoes and English peas in flat big salad bowl.
The advertisement is a joke. It made me watch 5 mins of ads and still not showing me the video of how to make the dish. Forget it. Plenty of other online cooking tips!
May be Short Review but a Very Positive Review for Recipe to be prepared as Written. Thank you ! I had Positive Feedback for Days from my Company at the Table !
Absolutely superb!¬† I'll make this often.¬† Ina Garten is a genius!!
See Alton Browns version, flower chicken first. Also, use fresh small onions not frozen, partial boil them for one minute to release skin. Lastly, add Miso paste to stock to enhance flavor.
This was a really wonderful an delicious recipe. Will make this over and over!
Very favorable and worth the effort to make it for your family. It did take me about 45 minutes longer to complete than the 1 hour 15 minutes stated but it was very much worth it.

An easy recipe to follow and delicious. I used pearl onions which I braised in butter prior to cooking the mushrooms. I served it over smashed fingerling potatoes which soaked up the sauce that some said was too thin.

Deliciousness! I used a "Good Burgundy and cognac. Recipes are going to vary on things like the quality of ingredients, cooking skills, etc. Reviewers don't often take these things into consideration and blame a recipe? I loved it and will definitely make it again! Thank you, Ina! ¬†
I didn't have enough carrots. I suggest you make sure you have enough carrots it absorbs the salt and gives the sweet flavor. Even better on the 2nd day.
Meh... I made this tonight and overall it‚Äôs ok but nothing I‚Äôd make again. The chicken comes out nice and tender but it lacks flavor. I love Ina but I won‚Äôt be making this again.
Delicious. The cognac is a great addition!
Delicious and not time consuming. Doubled the carrots the second time around because there wasn't enough the first time I cooked the recipe. Chicken thighs were amazing. Definitely a keeper recipe
worst recipe ever way too much booze¬†

Turned out just ok. Way too much fat floating around with the olive oil and the bacon. Next time i‚Äùd drain some of the fat after cooking the bacon. Also thought it could use a bit more S&P. Worth a try though.
Wonderful recipe. Did have to add more flour-butter mixture to thicken enough. What do you call that??

I am a huge fan of everything Ina but was disappointed in this dish. I followed the recipe using cognac and French Burgundy wine. I found the taste to be too salty....and I am a huge salt lover. Also, the sauce was too watery.
For the effort, I will stick with her beef Bourgogne.....now THAT is amazing
Directions seemed off to me. Following them I ended up with a lot of undercooked vegetables and a very boozy soup. Ended up cooking down for an hour after the recipe was supposed to be finished.
Not so great ... made it because I usually like Ina's recipes for flavor and simplicity.¬† Julia rules

Made this for dinner. It was fabulous. My husband and I both enjoyed it. Tried to decide if we liked it better than Skillet Roasted Lemon Chicken. Couldn‚Äôt pick a favorite. We will have this again paired with baby Yukon gold potatoes and roasted broccoli. Superb. Thanks Ina!!

I usually love Ina‚Äôs recipes, but this one was not a favorite.  Next time I will use a larger chicken because so much sauce was left.  Also, I will use a white wine instead of red as the darkened appearance of the chicken mate was not good.
So blah. Needed much more salt and spices and more time in the oven. I doubled the salt and still needed more. It wasn‚Äôt spicy at all. Just not interesting nor very tasty.

Made this two days in advance of a girls' dinner ... raves all around.¬† Used Sangiovese for the wine.¬† BTW, seems frozen pearl onions are a seasonal holiday thing.¬† I would recommend getting a few boxes when they appear.

Just made this recipe. Was deee-lish! I couldn‚Äôt find the frozen baby onions in my local grocery store. Also couldn‚Äôt find fresh ones. All I could find were cocktail onions in a jar. Didn‚Äôt wanna take the risk in ruining the dish. However it was a hit! Thanks, Ina! You rock!

This is FANTASTIC and one of my favorite fireplace side dinners in the fall and winter! It's that time of year making this again! This is also my go to dish for having guests over for dinner lately! SO fantastic and a true French classic!! Thank you so much Ina! love you!¬†

Mine turned out a bit greasy. I don‚Äôt know what I did wrong. The flavor was excellent though. I think I should have trimmed the skin on my thighs a bit, or perhaps use a whole chicken I have cut myself.  I will make again and try the above.
After a trip to France, I bought a le creuset mainly just to make this.¬† My investment in the cookware and the recipe were so worth it!!!

For the most part, I made it as written and it was amazing. Only thing was that I used fresh pearl onions instead of frozen. Peeled and cleaned.
So good!!
This came out great. I didn‚Äôt have cognac, so I used bourbon and Cabernet Sauvignon, it seemed a little sweet. Overall everyone loved it.

I was intimidated to attempt this dish, but I was having a dinner party and thought this would be a delicious fall meal. I prepped all the veggies and cut up the chicken the night before because I knew I wouldn't have much time to actually put this together. With everything already prepped, it took about 3 hours to make. I felt like I was rushing the whole time, but then again I was also trying to do mashed potatoes, roasted root veggies and salad - but again, these were all prepped the night before so it really shouldn't have taken too much of my time. ANYWAY - it does take longer than an hour and half to make this, but when it was done, it was really amazing tasting. Everyone loved it - lots of rich, autumn flavors, and it kind of makes you feel sophisticated, you know? I didn't change anything about the recipe, except that I did not use a "good wine." I literally used a $3 bottle of cab and it still turned out delicious. I would agree with what some others are saying about the sauce not thickening though. Either serve in a shallow bowl with a soup spoon, or maybe try to add more flour towards the end. Great recipe!
Phenomenal. Made it several times. Always outstanding. Served it over quinoa & brown rice bought at Sam‚Äôs Club. Ina never disappoints.

My first try and it turned out amazing! ¬†Used a Pinot Noir from Rogue Valley of Oregon. ¬†Maybe next time I'll use some extra chicken breast because most of the family likes white meat. It was full of flavor!¬†
One of my most favorite Ina recipes. The burgundy gives the chicken such a tented, succulent texture. ‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è‚≠êÔ∏è

I have made Coq Au Vin several times through the years and I believe this is the best recipe I have made. It went together with little effort & was just right for a Saturday Night-at-Home dinner. Served with crusty bread & a good salad, what else do you need?
Outstanding recipe for Coq Au Vin. The flavour of the sauce was heaven. The chicken was juicy and almost fell apart. It‚Äôs been a keeper of mine for awhile.¬†
Excellent.

I‚Äôve made coq Au vin using several different recipes. This is hands down the best I‚Äôve ever had. Followed the recipe to the letter. The chicken came out juicy and tender and the sauce was so good it made me a little weak in the knees. Served it with mashed potatoes. The whole family loved it.

Surprised I had not yet made this before and don't recall which cookbook it's featured in.¬† Used all chicken thighs and it turned out fabulous!¬† I also added little new potatoes to the pot.¬† Was really good!¬† It's a keeper.¬† Everyone in the family loved.

My mom has all of Ina‚Äôs cookbooks‚Äî we‚Äôve never had a bad recipe from her. I remember this being one of my favorites. I have grown to love cooking more and more now that I am on my own, and I certainly plan to make this for my friends one night for dinner!
This recipe was delicious! I made it for Valentine‚Äôs Day dinner for my husband and we both loved it. Recipe was easy to follow and make. My house still smells wonderful this morning!
Great and easy to make

Just broke in my new Le Creuset with this dish and it was a winner. I will say I plan to tweak a few things next time: mine came out too thin in consistency and I attribute this in part to my frozen pearl onions, which were frozen in a solid block more or less - make sure yours are thawed and drained before adding. Next time I'll also increase the amount of roux for a thicker end result. I would also add more pancetta and garlic as I felt these flavors were a little lost. Still delicious and worth the effort!!!

video.name: The Barefoot Contessa Makes Coq au Vin
video.description: Ina Garten shares her recipe for French Coq au Vin using chicken, mushrooms, onions and bacon.
